title: AI Revolutionizes Roadway Maintenance: From Dashcams to Databases
description: Cities and states across the U.S. are increasingly using artificial intelligence to identify and prioritize road maintenance and safety issues. Hawaii is implementing a novel approach with dashcams, while other regions leverage shared AI databases to systematically tackle infrastructure problems and enhance roadway safety.
content: As America's crumbling infrastructure continues to pose significant safety risks, states are turning to cutting-edge solutions, including artificial intelligence, to ensure road safety. Hawaii's innovative approach involves distributing 1,000 dashcam... [939 chars]

title: Oracle bonds sell off as AI investment fuels investor concerns
description: Oracle bonds have taken a hit in recent days following a report that the cloud and artificial intelligence service provider plans to add another $38 billion to its heavy debt load to fund its AI infrastructure, according to analysts and investors.

title: Who is Yann LeCun, the 65-yr-old NYU professor who plans to leave Meta
description: AI pioneer Yann LeCun’s departure from Meta raises concerns about corporate control of AI. He believes large language models can’t achieve human-level reasoning, causing friction within Meta. LeCun supports open-source AI and doubts the concept of Artificial General Intelligence. His exit coincides with Meta’s shift in AI strategy, led by CEO Mark Zuckerberg.

title: From OpenAI to Google, firms channel billions into AI infrastructure as demand booms
description: Global tech companies are pouring billions into artificial intelligence infrastructure. Google will invest $40 billion in Texas data centers. Major deals involve NVIDIA, OpenAI, Microsoft, and Meta. These investments signal a massive scaling up of computing power for future AI services. The industry is rapidly building capacity to meet surging demand.

title: Cities and states are turning to AI to improve road safety
description: By JEFF McMURRAY As America’s aging roads fall further behind on much-needed repairs, cities and states are turning to artificial intelligence to spot the worst hazards and decide which fixes should come first.
